name: Beat CHOP
description: The Beat CHOP generates a variety of ramps, pulses and counters that are timed to the beats per minute and the sync as produced by the Beat Dialog.
summary: The Beat CHOP generates a variety of ramps, pulses and counters that are timed to the beats per minute and the sync as produced by the Beat Dialog.

parameters.name: Reference Operator
parameters.label: Reference Operator
parameters.description:
From Derivative
		
		
		
		
		Jump to navigation
		Jump to search
		
The Beat  generates a variety of ramps, pulses and counters that are timed to the beats per minute and the sync as produced by the Beat Dialog.		

You can generate a ramp every 1/4 1/2 1 2 4 8 32 beats.
You can generate ramps of any other length, like 12 beats per bar (ramp) and fractional beats like 3.33 beats per ramp.
You can generate a set of channels, where each channel is delayed relative to the prior channel. This is useful, for example, for moving eight objects delayed by one beat each.
There also is a counter of how many ramps it has generated.
The Count+Ramp type generates a continuously-rising ramp equal to the number of cycles since the start.
If Play Mode is set to Local Sequential, it doesn't look at start/end of the timeline (i.e. doesn't reset when the timeline loops), so is more appropriate for long improvised playing.Note: for the purposes of this dialog, a bar is 4 beats and the period is the number of beats set by the Period parameter.
The Beat Dialog is used to manually tap the beat to set the beats-per-minute (BPM). The Beat  converts the BPM into a repeating ramp or pulse that keeps time with the music after you stop tapping.		
You can set the global beats-per-minute with the python command:  op('/local/time').tempo = 140
The phase can be controlled with the Beat 's Reset parameters. 
The Beat 's timing is defined by the Component Time of the  .  If the  Node parameter is left blank, then the time defined at the Beat 's location is used. The default is in /local/time.	
See also: Timeline CHOP, Time COMP.
beatCHOP_Class

Contents
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 





  op - This node is used to specify the time settings referenced by the Beat . The time is defined by the Time  found at timepath("reference_node")


		
  reftimeslice - Turn on this checkbox to use the Time Slicing used by the  .


		
  playmode -  - Specifies the method used to playback the output.

 locked - This mode locks the output to the local component Timeline. Scrubbing or jumping in the local time will update the output accordingly. When the local timeline loops the output is reset and starts over. The output will be the same for each pass through the local timeline. global - This mode locks the output to the Global beat source. It will follow the Beat  with whose 'Update Global' flag is turned on. local - This mode produces a continuous output regardless of the timeline position.
		
  period - Number of beats it takes to generate one cycle of ramp.	Use the drop down menu to select from some commonly used Period lengths.


			
  multiples - The number of channels to create.


		
  shiftoffset - Delays all channels by this amount. 0 = no change, .5 means 50% of one period later.


		
  shiftstep - When set to 1, and Multiples is 5, each ramp channel is 1/5 cycle later than the previous channel. When set to .1, the delay is 1/50 cycle. This is a way to stagger the channels.


		
  randoffset - The amount that each ramp is randomly time-shifted relative to a perfect ramp.


		
  randseed - Changing this generates a different set of random offsets.


		
  resetcondition -  - This menu determines how the Reset input triggers a reset of the channel(s).

 offtoon - Channels are reset when the Reset input goes off to on. on - Channels are reset when the Reset input goes on. The channel will hold the reset value until the input turns off. ontooff - Channels are reset when the Reset input goes on to off. off - Channels are reset when the Reset input goes off. The channel will hold the reset value until the input turns on.
		
  resetbarvalue - Specifies which Bar the Beat  will jump to when the Reset Condition is met. Beat values are derived from the fractional part of this value.


		
  resetwait - When using the While On Reset Condition, Wait After Reset will hold the channels at zero until the next bar is started, after which the output will continue. When Wait After Reset is off, the channels will restart output as soon as the reset condition is done.


		
  reset - This button resets the ramps to zero when On. The ramp is also zero when the Beat 's input is above 0.


		
  resetpulse - Instantly resets the ramps to zero.


		
  updateglobal - Any Beat  can be made the "global beat source" by turning on Update Global. A reference Beat  is created at /local/master_beat (if it doesn't already exist) and all Beat CHOPs can synchronize to this by setting 'Play Mode: Locked to Global'. That master Beat  also needs 'Update Global' turned on, if not already on. This means you require exactly one master Beat  per toe. You can turn switch back to 'Play Mode: Locked to Sequential' when desired.  $MASTER_BEAT is set to whatever Beat  has this option turned on.





  ramp - Outputs a 0-1 ramp each period.


		
  pulse - Outputs a pulse each period.


		
  sine - Outputs a sine wave each period.


		
  count - Increases the count each period.


		
  countramp - A ramp that counts up until the bar is reset.


		
  bar - Output the current bar.


		
  beat - Output the current beat.


		
  sixteenths - Output the current sixteenths.


		
  rampbar - Outputs a 0-1 ramp each bar.


		
  rampbeat - Outputs a 0-1 ramp each beat.


		
  bpm - Outputs the current BPM.





  timeslice - Turning this on forces the channels to be "Time Sliced".  A  is the time between the last cook frame and the current cook frame.



  scope - To determine which channels get affected, some CHOPs use a  string on the Common page.



  srselect -  - Handle cases where multiple input CHOPs' sample rates are different. When Resampling occurs, the curves are interpolated according to the Interpolation Method Option, or "Linear" if the Interpolate Options are not available.

 first - Use rate of first input to resample others. max - Resample to the highest sample rate. min - Resample to the lowest sample rate. err - Doesn't accept conflicting sample rates.

  exportmethod -  - This will determine how to connect the  channel to the parameter. Refer to the Export article for more information.

 datindex - Uses the docked  table and references the channel via the index of the channel in the . datname - Uses the docked  table and references the channel via the name of the channel in the . autoname - The channel is the full destination of where to export to, such has geo1/transform1:tx.

  autoexportroot - This path points to the root node where all of the paths that exporting by Channel Name is : are relative to.



  exporttable - The  used to hold the export information when using the  Table  Methods (See above).





 -
 -

Extra Information for the Beat  can be accessed via an Info CHOP.



 - Start of the  interval in samples. - Number of samples in the . - The samplerate of the channels in frames per second. - Number of channels in the . - 1 if  is  enabled, 0 otherwise. - A count of how often the export connections have been updated.
 - Number of times the operator has cooked since the process started. - Duration of the last cook in milliseconds. - Frame number when this operator was last cooked relative to the component timeline. - Frame number when this operator was last cooked relative to the absolute time. - Time in milliseconds at which the operator started cooking in the frame it was cooked. - Time in milliseconds at which the operator finished cooking in the frame it was cooked. - 1 if operator was cooked this frame. - Number of warnings in this operator if any. - Number of errors in this operator if any.
						TouchDesigner Build: Latest\nwikieditorwikieditorwikieditorwikieditor2022.241402021.100002018.28070before 2018.28070
CHOPs
• • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • 

An Operator Family which operate on Channels (a sequence of numbers (Samples)) which are used for animation, audio, mathematics, simulation, logic, UI construction, and data streamed from/to devices and protocols.



A Link. The grey dashed lines between nodes is a Reference or Link that indicates one operator is getting data from another operator from any Operator Family.


The grey dashed lines between nodes is a Reference (or Link). A Reference is (1) a Parameter Reference, a parameter in an OP that is a name or path to another operator, (2) a Node Reference, an expression in a parameter or DAT script that contains the name or path of another operator, (3) a DAT Cell Reference or (4) a CHOP Channel Reference.


A Link or Reference is a dashed line between nodes that represent other data flowing between nodes. Examples are CHOP Exports, node Paths in parameters, and expressions in parameters referencing CHOP channels, DAT tables and other nodes. In contrast is a Wire that connects nodes in the same Operator Family.



The generic thing that holds an Operator, and includes Flags (display, bypass, lock, render, immune) and its position/size in the network. Whether you "lay down an Operator" or "lay down an Node", you're doing the same thing.



Any of the procedural data operators. OPs do all the work in TouchDesigner. They "cook" and output data to other OPs, which ultimately result in new images, data and audio being generated. See Node.



An Operator Family that contains its own Network. There are sixteen 3D Object Component and ten 2D Panel Component types. See also Network Path.



A Time Slice is the time from the last cook frame to the current cook frame. In CHOPs it is the set of short channels that contain the CHOP channels' samples between the last and the current cook frame.



The panel at the bottom of TouchDesigner, it controls the current global looping Time your TouchDesigner project, or of just one component.



To "pulse" a parameter is to send it a signal from (1) an exported CHOP channel or (2) a python command or (3) a mouse click that causes a new action to occur immediately. A pulse via python is via the .pulse() function on a pulse-type parameter, such as Reset parameter in a Speed CHOP. A pulse from a CHOP is typically a 0 to 1 to 0 signal in an exported channel.



A parameter in most CHOPs that restricts which channels of that CHOP will be affected. Normally all channels of a CHOP are affected by the operator. TOPs have Channel Mask, a similar feature.



samples-per-second of a CHOP. Each CHOP in your network has a sample rate. In contrast, the overall timeline has a Frame Rate, which is the number of frames to cook and display per second, generally your monitor display frequency, default 60.



Exporting is the connection of CHOP channels to parameters of operators. The output of each exporting CHOP is one or more channels, active only while the CHOP Viewer is on. The current value of a channel can be exported to a parameter of any operator, overriding that parameter's value. See Parameter.



An Operator Family that manipulates text strings: multi-line text or tables. Multi-line text is often a python Script or GLSL Shader, but can be any multi-line text. Tables are rows and columns of cells, each containing a text string.



The location of an operator within the TouchDesigner environment, for example, /geo1/circle1, a node called circle1 in a component called geo1. The path / is called Root. This path is displayed at the top of every Pane, showing which Component's network you are currently in. To refer instead to a filesystem folder, directory, disk file or http: address, see Folder.



Every operator in TouchDesigner has a set of control Parameters that can be integer or floating point numbers, menus, binary toggles, text strings or operator paths, which determine the output of the operator.



TouchDesigner is a hierarchy of components. "root" is the top-most network in the hierarchy. The Network Path or Path for root is simply /. A typical path is /project1/moviein1.








Retrieved from "https://docs.derivative.ca/index.php?title=Beat_CHOP&oldid=32398"
		Category: CHOPs

  bpm - Outputs the current BPM.





  timeslice - Turning this on forces the channels to be "Time Sliced".  A  is the time between the last cook frame and the current cook frame.



  scope - To determine which channels get affected, some CHOPs use a  string on the Common page.



  srselect -  - Handle cases where multiple input CHOPs' sample rates are different. When Resampling occurs, the curves are interpolated according to the Interpolation Method Option, or "Linear" if the Interpolate Options are not available.

 first - Use rate of first input to resample others. max - Resample to the highest sample rate. min - Resample to the lowest sample rate. err - Doesn't accept conflicting sample rates.

  exportmethod -  - This will determine how to connect the  channel to the parameter. Refer to the Export article for more information.

 datindex - Uses the docked  table and references the channel via the index of the channel in the . datname - Uses the docked  table and references the channel via the name of the channel in the . autoname - The channel is the full destination of where to export to, such has geo1/transform1:tx.

  autoexportroot - This path points to the root node where all of the paths that exporting by Channel Name is : are relative to.



  exporttable - The  used to hold the export information when using the  Table  Methods (See above).





 -
 -

Extra Information for the Beat  can be accessed via an Info CHOP.



 - Start of the  interval in samples. - Number of samples in the . - The samplerate of the channels in frames per second. - Number of channels in the . - 1 if  is  enabled, 0 otherwise. - A count of how often the export connections have been updated.
 - Number of times the operator has cooked since the process started. - Duration of the last cook in milliseconds. - Frame number when this operator was last cooked relative to the component timeline. - Frame number when this operator was last cooked relative to the absolute time. - Time in milliseconds at which the operator started cooking in the frame it was cooked. - Time in milliseconds at which the operator finished cooking in the frame it was cooked. - 1 if operator was cooked this frame. - Number of warnings in this operator if any. - Number of errors in this operator if any.
						TouchDesigner Build: Latest\nwikieditorwikieditorwikieditorwikieditor2022.241402021.100002018.28070before 2018.28070
CHOPs
• • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • • 

An Operator Family which operate on Channels (a sequence of numbers (Samples)) which are used for animation, audio, mathematics, simulation, logic, UI construction, and data streamed from/to devices and protocols.



A Link. The grey dashed lines between nodes is a Reference or Link that indicates one operator is getting data from another operator from any Operator Family.


The grey dashed lines between nodes is a Reference (or Link). A Reference is (1) a Parameter Reference, a parameter in an OP that is a name or path to another operator, (2) a Node Reference, an expression in a parameter or DAT script that contains the name or path of another operator, (3) a DAT Cell Reference or (4) a CHOP Channel Reference.


A Link or Reference is a dashed line between nodes that represent other data flowing between nodes. Examples are CHOP Exports, node Paths in parameters, and expressions in parameters referencing CHOP channels, DAT tables and other nodes. In contrast is a Wire that connects nodes in the same Operator Family.



The generic thing that holds an Operator, and includes Flags (display, bypass, lock, render, immune) and its position/size in the network. Whether you "lay down an Operator" or "lay down an Node", you're doing the same thing.



Any of the procedural data operators. OPs do all the work in TouchDesigner. They "cook" and output data to other OPs, which ultimately result in new images, data and audio being generated. See Node.



An Operator Family that contains its own Network. There are sixteen 3D Object Component and ten 2D Panel Component types. See also Network Path.



A Time Slice is the time from the last cook frame to the current cook frame. In CHOPs it is the set of short channels that contain the CHOP channels' samples between the last and the current cook frame.



The panel at the bottom of TouchDesigner, it controls the current global looping Time your TouchDesigner project, or of just one component.



To "pulse" a parameter is to send it a signal from (1) an exported CHOP channel or (2) a python command or (3) a mouse click that causes a new action to occur immediately. A pulse via python is via the .pulse() function on a pulse-type parameter, such as Reset parameter in a Speed CHOP. A pulse from a CHOP is typically a 0 to 1 to 0 signal in an exported channel.



A parameter in most CHOPs that restricts which channels of that CHOP will be affected. Normally all channels of a CHOP are affected by the operator. TOPs have Channel Mask, a similar feature.



samples-per-second of a CHOP. Each CHOP in your network has a sample rate. In contrast, the overall timeline has a Frame Rate, which is the number of frames to cook and display per second, generally your monitor display frequency, default 60.



Exporting is the connection of CHOP channels to parameters of operators. The output of each exporting CHOP is one or more channels, active only while the CHOP Viewer is on. The current value of a channel can be exported to a parameter of any operator, overriding that parameter's value. See Parameter.



An Operator Family that manipulates text strings: multi-line text or tables. Multi-line text is often a python Script or GLSL Shader, but can be any multi-line text. Tables are rows and columns of cells, each containing a text string.



The location of an operator within the TouchDesigner environment, for example, /geo1/circle1, a node called circle1 in a component called geo1. The path / is called Root. This path is displayed at the top of every Pane, showing which Component's network you are currently in. To refer instead to a filesystem folder, directory, disk file or http: address, see Folder.



Every operator in TouchDesigner has a set of control Parameters that can be integer or floating point numbers, menus, binary toggles, text strings or operator paths, which determine the output of the operator.



TouchDesigner is a hierarchy of components. "root" is the top-most network in the hierarchy. The Network Path or Path for root is simply /. A typical path is /project1/moviein1.








Retrieved from "https://docs.derivative.ca/index.php?title=Beat_CHOP&oldid=32398"

parameters.name: Reference Operator
parameters.label: Reference Operator
parameters.description: op - This node is used to specify the time settings referenced by the Beat . The time is defined by the Time  found at timepath("reference_node")

parameters.name: Use Reference Time Slice
parameters.label: Use Reference Time Slice
parameters.description: reftimeslice - Turn on this checkbox to use the Time Slicing used by the  .

parameters.name: Play Mode
parameters.label: Play Mode
parameters.description:
playmode -  - Specifies the method used to playback the output.

 locked - This mode locks the output to the local component Timeline. Scrubbing or jumping in the local time will update the output accordingly. When the local timeline loops the output is reset and starts over. The output will be the same for each pass through the local timeline. global - This mode locks the output to the Global beat source. It will follow the Beat  with whose 'Update Global' flag is turned on. local - This mode produces a continuous output regardless of the timeline position.

parameters.name: Locked to Timeline
parameters.label: Locked to Timeline
parameters.description: locked - This mode locks the output to the local component Timeline. Scrubbing or jumping in the local time will update the output accordingly. When the local timeline loops the output is reset and starts over. The output will be the same for each pass through the local timeline. global - This mode locks the output to the Global beat source. It will follow the Beat  with whose 'Update Global' flag is turned on. local - This mode produces a continuous output regardless of the timeline position.

parameters.name: Period
parameters.label: Period
parameters.description: period - Number of beats it takes to generate one cycle of ramp.	Use the drop down menu to select from some commonly used Period lengths.

parameters.name: Multiples
parameters.label: Multiples
parameters.description: multiples - The number of channels to create.

parameters.name: Shift Offset
parameters.label: Shift Offset
parameters.description: shiftoffset - Delays all channels by this amount. 0 = no change, .5 means 50% of one period later.

parameters.name: Shift Step
parameters.label: Shift Step
parameters.description: shiftstep - When set to 1, and Multiples is 5, each ramp channel is 1/5 cycle later than the previous channel. When set to .1, the delay is 1/50 cycle. This is a way to stagger the channels.

parameters.name: Random Offset
parameters.label: Random Offset
parameters.description: randoffset - The amount that each ramp is randomly time-shifted relative to a perfect ramp.

parameters.name: Random Seed
parameters.label: Random Seed
parameters.description: randseed - Changing this generates a different set of random offsets.

parameters.name: Reset Condition
parameters.label: Reset Condition
parameters.description:
resetcondition -  - This menu determines how the Reset input triggers a reset of the channel(s).

 offtoon - Channels are reset when the Reset input goes off to on. on - Channels are reset when the Reset input goes on. The channel will hold the reset value until the input turns off. ontooff - Channels are reset when the Reset input goes on to off. off - Channels are reset when the Reset input goes off. The channel will hold the reset value until the input turns on.

parameters.name: Off to On
parameters.label: Off to On
parameters.description: offtoon - Channels are reset when the Reset input goes off to on. on - Channels are reset when the Reset input goes on. The channel will hold the reset value until the input turns off. ontooff - Channels are reset when the Reset input goes on to off. off - Channels are reset when the Reset input goes off. The channel will hold the reset value until the input turns on.

parameters.name: Reset Bar Value
parameters.label: Reset Bar Value
parameters.description: resetbarvalue - Specifies which Bar the Beat  will jump to when the Reset Condition is met. Beat values are derived from the fractional part of this value.

parameters.name: Wait after Reset
parameters.label: Wait after Reset
parameters.description: resetwait - When using the While On Reset Condition, Wait After Reset will hold the channels at zero until the next bar is started, after which the output will continue. When Wait After Reset is off, the channels will restart output as soon as the reset condition is done.

parameters.name: Reset
parameters.label: Reset
parameters.description: reset - This button resets the ramps to zero when On. The ramp is also zero when the Beat 's input is above 0.

parameters.name: Reset Pulse
parameters.label: Reset Pulse
parameters.description: resetpulse - Instantly resets the ramps to zero.

parameters.name: Update Global
parameters.label: Update Global
parameters.description: updateglobal - Any Beat  can be made the "global beat source" by turning on Update Global. A reference Beat  is created at /local/master_beat (if it doesn't already exist) and all Beat CHOPs can synchronize to this by setting 'Play Mode: Locked to Global'. That master Beat  also needs 'Update Global' turned on, if not already on. This means you require exactly one master Beat  per toe. You can turn switch back to 'Play Mode: Locked to Sequential' when desired.  $MASTER_BEAT is set to whatever Beat  has this option turned on.

parameters.name: Ramp
parameters.label: Ramp
parameters.description: ramp - Outputs a 0-1 ramp each period.

parameters.name: Pulse
parameters.label: Pulse
parameters.description: pulse - Outputs a pulse each period.

parameters.name: Sine
parameters.label: Sine
parameters.description: sine - Outputs a sine wave each period.

parameters.name: Count
parameters.label: Count
parameters.description: count - Increases the count each period.

parameters.name: Count+Ramp
parameters.label: Count+Ramp
parameters.description: countramp - A ramp that counts up until the bar is reset.

parameters.name: Bar
parameters.label: Bar
parameters.description: bar - Output the current bar.

parameters.name: Beat
parameters.label: Beat
parameters.description: beat - Output the current beat.

parameters.name: Sixteenths
parameters.label: Sixteenths
parameters.description: sixteenths - Output the current sixteenths.

parameters.name: Ramp Bar
parameters.label: Ramp Bar
parameters.description: rampbar - Outputs a 0-1 ramp each bar.

parameters.name: Ramp Beat
parameters.label: Ramp Beat
parameters.description: rampbeat - Outputs a 0-1 ramp each beat.

parameters.name: BPM
parameters.label: BPM
parameters.description: bpm - Outputs the current BPM.

parameters.name: Time Slice
parameters.label: Time Slice
parameters.description: timeslice - Turning this on forces the channels to be "Time Sliced".  A  is the time between the last cook frame and the current cook frame.

parameters.name: Scope
parameters.label: Scope
parameters.description: scope - To determine which channels get affected, some CHOPs use a  string on the Common page.

parameters.name: Sample Rate Match
parameters.label: Sample Rate Match
parameters.description:
srselect -  - Handle cases where multiple input CHOPs' sample rates are different. When Resampling occurs, the curves are interpolated according to the Interpolation Method Option, or "Linear" if the Interpolate Options are not available.

 first - Use rate of first input to resample others. max - Resample to the highest sample rate. min - Resample to the lowest sample rate. err - Doesn't accept conflicting sample rates.

parameters.name: Resample At First Input's Rate
parameters.label: Resample At First Input's Rate
parameters.description: first - Use rate of first input to resample others. max - Resample to the highest sample rate. min - Resample to the lowest sample rate. err - Doesn't accept conflicting sample rates.

parameters.label: Export Method
parameters.description:
exportmethod -  - This will determine how to connect the  channel to the parameter. Refer to the Export article for more information.

 datindex - Uses the docked  table and references the channel via the index of the channel in the . datname - Uses the docked  table and references the channel via the name of the channel in the . autoname - The channel is the full destination of where to export to, such has geo1/transform1:tx.

parameters.name: Export Root
parameters.label: Export Root
parameters.description: autoexportroot - This path points to the root node where all of the paths that exporting by Channel Name is : are relative to.
